The bridge was originally named Khedive Ismail Bridge after King Fuad's father, [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha]]. After the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952]], the name of the bridge, as well as other Egyptian buildings and bridges, were changed. This bridge was renamed ''Qasr al-Nil'' in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], which translates as Palace of the Nile. <ref name="latimes">{{cite news |title=Cairoâs bridge of dreams |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/14/world/fg-bridge14 |author=Fleishman, Jeffrey |date=August 14, 2007 |publisher=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>.
The bridge was originally named Khedive Ismail Bridge after King Fuad's father, [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha]]. After the [[Egyptian Revolution of 1952]], the name of the bridge, as well as other Egyptian buildings and bridges, were changed. This bridge was renamed ''Qasr al-Nil'' in [[Arabic language|Arabic]], which translates as Palace of the Nile. <ref name="latimes">{{cite news |title=Cairoâs bridge of dreams |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2007/aug/14/world/fg-bridge14 |author=Fleishman, Jeffrey |date=August 14, 2007 |publisher=Los Angeles Times}}</ref>.
â
==Public use==
+
==Public use and demonstrations==
â
The Qasr al-Nil Bridge, with sidewalks, is popular for strolling in the evenings. The bridge offers views of the river, as well as landmark buildings, hotels, and other structures on the island and along the Corniche Al-Nile on the west bank. The bridge is popular as location for young Egyptian friends and couples to have an inexpensive outdoor date.
+
The Qasr al-Nil Bridge, with sidewalks, is popular for strolling in the evenings. The bridge offers views of the river, as well as landmark buildings, hotels, and other structures on the island and along the Corniche Al-Nile on the west bank. The bridge is popular as location for young Egyptian friends and couples to have an inexpensive outdoor date.
  +
===2011 Egyptian Revolution===
  +
{{main|2011 Egyptian Revolution}}
The bridge has been an ongoing site in the [[2011 Egyptian protests]], along with the nearby [[6th October Bridge]], for public demonstrations on it and as a major route east to the ''Midan Tahrir''âTahrir Square protest gatherings. <ref>BBC News: [http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12312330 "Egypt protests: curfew defied in Cairo and other cities"] 29 January 2011 . accessed 2011.01.29.]</ref>
